channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Bits Blog: Facebook’s Secret Manipulation of User Emotions Faces European Inquiries
item.description: The social network is facing potential investigations in Europe on whether it broke local privacy laws by manipulating the emotional content of users’ posts without their consent.
item.dc:creator: By VINDU GOEL
item.media:description: Facebook said last week that it deliberately manipulated the emotional content of posts in the news feeds of nearly 700,000 users to see if emotions were contagious.

item.title: Italian Leader Presses His Case for Budget Relief in Europe
item.description: Prime Minister Matteo Renzi means to use Italy’s six-month tenure in the European Union presidency to promote policies that focus on growth.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER

item.title: Sarkozy Lashes Out at Prosecution in Corruption Case
item.description: The former French president Nicolas Sarkozy, after being detained for 15 hours, called investigators’ accusations against him “preposterous.”
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY and MAÏA de la BAUME
item.media:description: Nicolas Sarkozy, the former president of France, outside his Paris home on Wednesday.

item.title: Sports of The Times: World Cup 2014: America’s Love Affair With Tim Howard May Be Fleeting
item.description: Tim Howard’s brilliance in the United States’ loss to Belgium at the World Cup was an inspiration to Americans, some of whom took their adulation to amusing lengths.
item.category: United States Men's National Soccer Team
item.dc:creator: By JULIET MACUR
item.media:description: Tim Howard did all he could to save the United States in a 2-1 loss to Belgium.

item.title: African Leaders Grant Themselves Immunity in Proposed Court
item.description: African leaders have voted to give themselves immunity from prosecution for crimes against humanity, war crimes and genocide in an African human rights court that does not yet exist.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: Benghazi Attack Suspect Ordered Held Until Trial
item.description: A federal judge accepted government arguments that Ahmed Abu Khattala should be kept in custody because he poses a threat to the United States.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT

item.title: China Expels 3 Officials in Corruption Inquiry
item.description: The expulsions of the three men, who had ties to the former Politburo Standing Committee member Zhou Yongkang, were the latest sign that officials may announce charges against Mr. Zhou himself.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID BARBOZA

item.title: Privacy Board Backs N.S.A. Program That Taps Internet in U.S.
item.description: The federal board, which sharply criticized the collection of Americans’ phone records, has come to a starkly different conclusion about the exploitation of Internet connections in the U.S. to monitor foreigners.
item.category: Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: As Tear Gas Wafts Outside, Palestinian Family Mourns
item.description: The killing of a Palestinian teenager set off unrest, even as his father urged Arabs and Israelis to end the bloodshed.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER and SAID GHAZALI
item.media:credit: Rina Castelnuovo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Suha Abu Khdeir, 44, center, mourns Muhammad, 16, her son.

item.title: 8 Afghan Air Force Officers Killed in Suicide Attack in Kabul
item.description: The assailant boarded a bus carrying Afghan Air Force officers, in one of the first major attacks in Kabul in months as the Taliban turned its focus elsewhere.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED and JAWAD SUKHANYAR

item.title: Russia Demands New Cease-Fire in Ukraine
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin said Russia would move aggressively to protect the interests of “Russian people” in eastern Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: A pro-Russian fighter patrolled on Wednesday near Luhansk, eastern Ukraine.

item.title: Unarmed Drones Aid U.N. Peacekeepers in Africa
item.description: Limits on the aircraft have emerged, including those imposed by their range, flying conditions and whether host countries grant permission.
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.media:description: A surveillance drone belonging to the United Nations at the airport in Goma, Democratic Republic of Congo.

item.title: Suicide Bomber Kills 8 in Afghan Capital
item.description: A Taliban suicide bomber attacked an Afghan air force bus in Kabul Wednesday, killing at least eight military personnel, officials said, as the militants step up their campaign of violence aimed at undermining the Western-backed government.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Putin Warns Again of Force as Ukraine Fighting Spreads
item.description: Fighting resumed in the east early Tuesday, including artillery shelling around the rebel-controlled city of Slovyansk, after President Petro O. Poroshenko ended a 10-day cease-fire.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: A resident surveyed damage from recent shelling in Slovyansk, Ukraine, on Tuesday.

item.title: China’s President to Visit South Korea
item.description: The visit to Seoul by President Xi Jinping of China appears to be aimed at disrupting the alliances the United States has developed in the region.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ

item.title: American Ship Loaded with Toxic Syrian Chemicals
item.description: The cargo is part of a 1,300-ton stockpile of toxins removed from Syria under an international deal brokered last year and brought to Italy.
item.category: Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO and ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: The Cape Ray on Wednesday began loading toxic chemicals from Syria at a port in Italy for destruction at sea.

item.title: Iraqi Premier Says Fight Against ISIS Is Top Priority
item.description: Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki said defeating extremist Sunni groups was more important than bridging Iraq’s political divide to form a unity government.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND
item.media:description: Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki of Iraq, center, with lawmakers on Tuesday.

item.title: Tension Mounts After Apparent Revenge Killing in Jerusalem
item.description: In what may have been a retaliation for the kidnapping and killing of three Israeli teenagers, a body was discovered on Wednesday after a report that a Palestinian teenager had been forced into a car.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER and JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: Palestinian protesters threw stones at Israeli police during clashes on Wednesday in Shuafat, a neighborhood in Jerusalem.

item.title: Uphill Fight Ahead for Hong Kong’s Democracy Movement
item.description: Hong Kong’s huge pro-democracy march Tuesday underscored the determination of many of its residents to preserve their freedoms but also brought some challenges to light.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Bangladesh’s Rotten-Mango Crisis
item.description: A dispute over contaminated mangoes reveals a growing chasm between the city and the country.
item.dc:creator: By TAHMIMA ANAM

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China Sees Long Road to Cleaning Up Pollution
item.description: A state-run newspaper says it will take at least 16 years for China to attain safe levels of dangerous particulate matter in its air, but even that is in doubt.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: A man wearing a mask on a smoggy day in Beijing in March.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The Caliphate Fantasy
item.description: ISIS claims to have restored an Islamic state, but the reality of the caliphs was far different from what the jihadists imagine.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By KHALED DIAB

item.title: Pistorius at Increasing Risk of Suicide, Lawyer Says
item.description: A psychologist’s report read at the South African athlete’s murder trial said he needs to be treated for post-traumatic stress and depression.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Cybercrime Scheme Aims at Payments in Brazil
item.description: Researchers say transactions worth $3.75 billion were compromised, though it is not clear how much was stolen.
item.dc:creator: By NICOLE PERLROTH

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: In Hong Kong, a Potent Visual Echo of Tiananmen
item.description: Amid the protesters in the city on Tuesday was a papier-mâché replica of the Goddess of Democracy statue, the icon of the 1989 Tiananmen Square protests, this one built by students born years after Beijing’s bloody crackdown.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE
item.media:description: Marchers carried a scaled-down replica of the Goddess of Democracy, an icon of the 1989 protests in Tiananmen Square in Beijing, during Hong Kong's pro-democracy demonstration Tuesday.
